Let me follow up that on that point with you, Justin, because how can you tell, for example, that a blogger is black?
Is it by what they say or what they talk about?
Should we even be able to tell?
Well, I think Greg touched on that.
It's a - it relates to the pop culture references.
In the sports blog world, you see a lot of melding between sports and what's going on in pop culture.
So - and on Alphablogsports, you know, we've had numerous references to our hip-hop comparisons - comparing athletes to rappers and things like that.
So that's the type of thing you're going to see on a black blog.
On a white blog, you're going to have more of that white, you know, sarcastic frat-guy type of attitude.
So you should be able to tell just by reading, that's what you're saying?
Yeah, you can tell which culture the writer has come from just by reading it.
This is for all three of you.
What about credibility?
How can you tell who - for example, one of you just talked about the Boston Red Sox being in a bar after they won the division.
How can you tell what's credible on a blog and what's not?
Let me start with you, Mike.
It really just depends on what's their perspective.
I don't like - us at The Starting Five, we really want the reader to be informed through our research.
We really want to make sure the reader gets a proper perspective and then can also think for themselves as it relates to the stories that we post.
Like, I used the interview a lot of ESPN journalists or journalists - any kind of journalists.
And I really want them to get across their opinions that they can't write on ESPN.
Well, you know, Greg, you're an editor at the Boston Sports at the Boston Globe online.
How much editing is involved in blogging and how do you figure out who's credible and who's not in the blogosphere?
Well, we have a different definition of blog.
In the blog arena, it's very sort of complicated.

I had dinner with a sports - a (unintelligible) coach a couple of weeks ago, and he made a statement that there are so many different outlets out there that bloggers are really - it tends - it hurts the mainstream media in terms of like the beat riders, like they can't tell who's who.
It's - he gave the example how, you know, there's the blogger at ESPN, the sport's guy, and he's real good, Bill Simmons.

He has great humor, a great writing touch, but the things that he writes in terms of, like, you know, critical analysis of players or stuff like that he's never in a locker room to really talk to them to actually face up after criticizing them.
And it really - and so you can't really tell, you know, who's credible in terms of actually being, you know.
At the Boston Globe, we have blogs but more news updates of what's going on during the day with a particular team.
I mean, if you write anything critical, the reporters are dead the next day to face the music with that subject.
So there's a - there's two types of, you know, things.
Newspapers are trying to figure out how to get in the blog, you know, be in a blog but there's a different definition of blogs in newspapers than any other venues.
Let me reset the table before we go on to our next topic.
In case you are just joining us, this is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Tony Cox.

This is our first ever sports Blog Roundtable, and we are joined by Justin Grant who is a writer for Alphablogsports, Mike Tillery who writes for the blog Starting Five, and Gregory Lee is online sports editor for the Boston Globe.
Justin, it just so happened because this was our first blog that when we invited the three of you that you turned out to be guys.
It wasn't designed to be that way, but let's talk about gender and females who are in the blogosphere.
Are they present?
I know that they are present, but are they present in a large number?
Well, you know, for me, the only prominent female journalist I know is Jemele Hill on ESPN - scratch that - also Selena Roberts for the New York Times.
But I think that as far as the blog world is concern, it kind of reflects real life.
Primary men are the main sports fans, and because blogs are driven by diehards, that's who's really doing most of the writing.
Mike, is that your view too?
That's my view too.
Yeah, we have - I think there's one prominent blogger.
Her name is - she writes from Leave the Man Alone, and she really writes from a woman's perspective.
I'm going to use Jemele here just to give that touch on our site but, no, there are not many female journalists.
I think it's even less than the black bloggers that are out there.
That's unfortunate.
You know, it's interesting you should say that because in terms of - let's take the Isiah Thomas case.
Everyone in the sports world knows about that, that he was found guilty of sexual harassment.
And there is this issue as to whether or not Al Sharpton is going to boycott him because he used - he being Thomas used the B-word in his testimony.

And some of the blogs that I have seen where the females have chimed in on this, they've been offended by some of the language that the bloggers used regardless as to the position they took over what Isiah Thomas said.
What about that, Greg?

Well, you know, the typical, you know, as we just talked about early about the most of the bloggers who are writing is more of - most of them is frat-boy-type of attitude that, you know, there aren't people who are there to, you know, to defend, you know, black females in the positions what Isiah Thomas that issue and that so and so.
There's really no one - there's no balancing out to challenge the write-ups of the bloggers.

As we said earlier, most of them are of the, you know, frat-boy mentality, which is, you know, there's no-holds-barred, so they can't - there's not really a context or perspective given on these blogs about what, you know, the offenses that Ms. Thomas had…
So we're going to - go on, finish the thought.
Especially about going to black women so there's no real perspective.
You know, most of the bloggers don't really have that kind of perspective.
They're not trying to go there.
If we go on the blog today, Mike, the hot topic is going to be what - the top two or three topics on the blog today?
Hey.
How's it going?
On the blog today - most likely is going to be the NFL, especially at this time of the week and we're really just talking about specifically the New England-Dallas game coming up this weekend.

So I guess we should go to Greg because Greg is in Boston and Beantown is really hot right now, Greg, with the Red Sox and the ALCS, the Patriots going up with their undefeated season so far and the Celtics who opened with Kevin Garnett and Ray Allen over in Europe.
The people in Boston are really blogging like crazy, I imagine.
Oh, yes, I read the various blogs in Boston.
And New England fans are unlike any other fans around country.
They are really rabid.
They're really passionate but they also really well read and they will read a lot of things.

I mean, you can't get enough of Red Sox material on our Web site, the same thing with the Patriots, with their running - playing a big game against Dallas this week and, of course, with the Celtics, it's going to be a big deal too.
So yes, the different Web sites we have that I read every day about what's going on with every team.
Everyone wants to know what's the latest with Manny Ramirez.
Will Jacoby Ellsberry start instead of Coco Crisp or J.D.
Drew.
So everyone is, you know, going to the sites and putting their take on those issues.
How much of these is regional, fellows?
Because I'm thinking now, we're in Los Angeles.
So the big blogosphere story in this part of the country is Kobe Bryant and whether or not Jerry Buss is willing to dump him this season or in the near future.
But I imagine that's not necessarily such a big topic in other parts of the country.
What about that, Justin?
Well, certainly, in New York, the big topic right now is Joe Torre's status with the New York Yankees.
From the sense that I'm getting in the New York blogs, a lot of people feel like Joe Torre has kind of been Bobby Cox-ing it through his past few seasons.

Meaning, that he has the calm approach just necessary to succeed during the regular season, but when the playoffs come, either he lacks the urgency that's needed to, you know, make the move to get his team over the top.
And then…
Even though he's won four World Series?
Even though he's won four.
You know, people have a very short memory in these sports.
What have you done for me lately?
And they haven't won in a long time.
New Yorkers are really tough.
I don't know if they're tougher than…
It is.
They're tougher now.
Philly or not.
Mike, what's your take about what the hot stories are in terms of how they differ from region to region?
And we're coming to the end of the time that we have.
Yes.
It really just depends on.
It seems the sports teams are located in your area.
Like, I'm a Yankees fan.
I think the whole thing with Joe Torre is about the lack of pitching.
That's one reason why they lose this time of year.
Yeah.
(Unintelligible).

But I think they really should be discussed nationally and if it's discussed out of New York, they maybe the national news will pick it up and speak about it more objectively instead of just saying, you know, these guys lost in the playoffs from year to year.
